title: The Study of Music
description: If music is to be found in every culture, acknowledgement of this fact does little to explain the complex ways in which music inhabits a culture. This class provides students with the opportunity to examine critically the ways in which music relates to cultures that differ in terms of place and time. To that end, the class is not organized around historical “style periods” or limited to any particular geographic region, but rather emphasizes a comparative approach that helps the student discover how their own assumptions about and understanding of music are culturally determined. The course will be organized around the study of music in relation to various socio-cultural frames: music and the domestic sphere, music and religion, music and politics.
outcome: Upon successfully completing this course, students will be able to: -Generalize about the ways in which music is employed within cultures -Compare specific examples of the cultural use of music -Write about music and music-making within reference to socio-cultural frameworks

title: Analysis and Performance
description: This course offers upper undergraduates the opportunity to explore the interactions between analysis and performance in tonal music. Factors that affect interpretative decisions such as the choice of editions, stylistic competency, historical performance practice, generic and formal expectations, rhythmic and metrical awareness, harmonic sensitivity and structural understanding will be addressed in turn. Concepts will be introduced primarily by way of scores and recordings, and readings will also be assigned where appropriate. Students should be prepared to engage in music making (singing and/or playing). This is a recommended course for performance stream students and an elective for others.
outcome: Upon successfully completing this course, students will be expected to demonstrate:  1. Analytical competence for tonal music in different styles, genres and periods;  2. Awareness of the main issues and concerns surrounding the performance of different repertoires;  3. Familiarity with the factors informing musical interpretation and the ways in which these may be communicated to the audience; 4. Ability to apply the concepts learnt to their own performance and/or research.

title: Approaches to Popular Music
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): MUSC2872 and MUSC2882 or permission by the instructor.
description: The course aims to provide a grounding in approaches to thinking and writing about popular music critically, with some theoretical and musicological background in musical, historical, and cultural issues. It will offer a historical overview of Anglophone popular music in the twentieth century, while also exploring a variety of approaches, perspectives, and key issues in relation to featured songs, videos, and case studies. More broadly, it aims (i) to give students a sense of the richness and diversity of the theoretical approaches to popular music of the Anglophone world, while exploring common links and themes; (ii) to ask fundamental questions about the social location of popular musics and their role in forming and responding to social practices; and (iii) to explore, where appropriate, connections with other cultural traditions and artistic media.

title: Traditional Musical Culture in China
requirements: For MA Music
description: Covering significant issues and topics in the study of Chinese music history, this course focuses on traditional Chinese music and its relevance to modern society. It aims to expose students to both Chinese and international scholarship by means of an up-to-date discussion of the historiography of Chinese music.

title: Musical Culture in Contemporary China
requirements: For MA Music
description: Focusing on the modernization, westernization and globalization faced by the Chinese since the early 20th century, this course deals with the survival, positioning and cultural environment of Chinese music. Based on recent scholarly discourse in China and the West, the course takes a multi-disciplinary approach to the study of contemporary Chinese music.
outcome: • Formulate a critical overview of the musical development in China from the late 19th century to the present  • Identify new issues and make informed judgments about new types of music by Chinese composers appearing in  Mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and overseas • Apply knowledge and skills in professional activities such as research and music performance • Develop creative and original responses to problems and issues found in the development of music in modern China.

title: Music and Popular Culture in Hong Kong
requirements: For MA Music
description: Music and culture are the points of departure. Popular song and film of Hong Kong are studied in relationship to the unique political, historical and cultural position of Hong Kong. The issue of identity will be further explored from the perspectives of cultural studies, ethnomusicology and musicology.
outcome: • Develop and reinforce critical insight from a wide spectrum of perspectives • Develop a postgraduate level of competence in critical thinking about various kinds of popular culture and the multifarious  meanings behind them

title: Music in Film
requirements: For MA Music
description: This course examines the role of music in film. It enables students with no training in music or media studies to better appreciate the art of film music. Through lectures and assignments that comprise viewing, reading, and listening, students gain skills to critically evaluate what they see and hear in feature films, animated films, music videos, and advertisements.
outcome: • Expand knowledge of film and gain a broad appreciation of the methods of film composers • Develop an understanding of how music and other sounds interact with visual images to communicate ideas • Enhance critical skills and develop the habit of questioning the meaning of what is seen and heard on screen

title: Frontiers in Church Music
requirements: For MA Music
description: The course surveys the significance of traditional Catholic and Protestant liturgies to the 21st century Christian Church. Theological, Biblical, pastoral and musical issues will be examined and analysed. Practical aspects of hymnology, choral music and liturgical music will be studied.

title: Music-Making in Global Contexts
requirements: For MA Music
description: This course provides an in depth study of how music is created and performed in various selected music cultures across the globe, with particular emphasis placed on how aesthetic systems of all types (classical, folk, popular, etc.) shape and are shaped by socio-cultural factors and mechanisms, such as place, identity, social structure, globalization, and social change.

title: Music Management and Promotion
requirements: For MA Music
description: The aim of the course is to enable students to learn the theoretical concepts of music management and promotion as well as to examine how these are applied in various music industries in Hong Kong. Students will thus acquire a better understanding of the context and the dissemination of music in the Hong Kong community. Their perspectives on music promotion and ability to analyze critical issues relating to music and society will be enhanced.
outcome: • Gain an overview of the fundamental concepts and skills in the management and promotion of music • Learn and benefit from experienced and successful practitioners in the field in the application of key concepts and skills in  real life situations

description: The course aims to provide students with knowledge and practical training in writing service music for specific functions. The students will be able to learn the techniques of writing music for educational purposes, the broadcasting industry, ceremony, film and television.

title: Practical Composing and Arranging
requirements: For MA Music
description: The course is designed as a practical guide, leading the arranger (as a composer) through the entire process of creative imagination to the completion of an arrangement and the preparation of a score. Students are introduced to the concepts of melodic construction, harmonic expansion, rhythmic elaboration, and techniques of modulation and variation. They will be given assignments to score for various texture types, compose introductions, transitions and codas, develop accompaniment styles, and to plan the form of an arrangement. Emphasis will be given to practical scoring for specifi c groups, such as for church and school choir, wind band and chamber orchestra. Considerations in popular music will also be discussed. Prerequisite: attained at least ABRSM Grade 8 (or equivalent) in theory.
outcome: • Acquire mastery of the musical language being employed for use • Develop the ability to treat and develop ideas in musically interesting ways • Develop consistency in writing in the styles concerned • Gain awareness of writing idiomatically for musical instruments and/or the human voice • Acquire the ability to communicate effectively through preparation of a musical score

title: Advanced Music Information Technology
requirements: For MA Music
description: This course introduces the usage and the application of the most up-to-date computer, audio engineering and electronic technology. Emphasis will be placed on both the theory and practicalities of computer music software and its application in the classroom and church. Students need to do studio work.
outcome: • Gain advanced knowledge of music technology and the vocabulary used in the field • Gain advanced knowledge and concepts of sound theory • Acquire skills of how to process and play back musical scores on the computer • Apply the techniques studied to electronic orchestration and explore their utility in various contexts such as classrooms or  church services • Apply technology more generally to assist in learning and working

title: Writing Music for the Church
requirements: For MA Music
description: The course is an extension of MUS8009. Designed in the form of a workshop, students are guided through the process of planning and developing a musical work along with the actual making of the music in class. Emphasis will be given to developing skills typically required for the church musician, including those of keyboard improvisation, practical scoring for ensembles of limited resource, musical setting for congregational hymns, and the writing of descant, varied accompaniment, worship chorus and anthem, etc. (Prerequisite: attained at least ABRSM Grade 8 Theory or equivalent. Contents: This 12-week term course is designed to study the formal structures of music and to familiarize music students with some of the most useful analytical tools. Some of the topics may include the thematic process of music; post Schenkerian theory; post-tonal understanding of music; and how listen to music structurally.

title: Seminar in Musicology: From 1870 to the Present
requirements: For students in Doctor of Music, Master of Music, MPhil Music or PhD Music
